content.raw:
```python
def __init__(self, result_list = [None for _ in TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES]):
    zipper = zip(result_list, TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES.keys())
    for value, name in zipper:
        setattr(self, name, value)
```

In the TrainInstanceResults class, during initialization after training, we input a list and match it to keys from this ordered dict for saving. If this dict were not in this order, it would not match the input list.
content.html:
def __init__(self, result_list = [None for _ in TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES]):
    zipper = zip(result_list, TRAIN_RESULT_TYPES.keys())
    for value, name in zipper:
        setattr(self, name, value)

In the TrainInstanceResults class, during initialization after training, we input a list and match it to keys from this ordered dict for saving. If this dict were not in this order, it would not match the input list.

content.raw:
This code is alarming only because it sets attributes regardless of what is passed to it. As in - if future parameters are added in one part of the code, it will not be caught as an error in other parts or vice-versa.

It would be great to actually define what class members are expected here \(and set them to a default of None if required\).

Instead of initializing with a list of arbitrary arguments, you can set based on `**kwargs` if you wish for a more explicit and shorthand form of initialization.
content.html:
This code is alarming only because it sets attributes regardless of what is passed to it. As in - if future parameters are added in one part of the code, it will not be caught as an error in other parts or vice-versa.

It would be great to actually define what class members are expected here (and set them to a default of None if required).

Instead of initializing with a list of arbitrary arguments, you can set based on **kwargs if you wish for a more explicit and shorthand form of initialization.

update.description:
# Segway Modular API Updates

## Introduction of Steps

This introduces a new API which divides the three Segway tasks, train, identify, and posterior, into steps allowing us to stop the processes at defined intervals to view and potentially modify the input files generated by Segway before and during training. The steps that have been defined are:

* init: Generates all input files, but does not submit any jobs to GMTK \(besides triangulate\). At the end of this step the input.master, segway.str, auxillary files, tri files, and the window.bed will all be generated.
* run: Submits jobs to GMTK. Produces params and viterbi files.
* finish: Selects the best training and identify instances and uses these to generate the output files.
* train-run-round: This step is specific to training. It will run a single round of training and then stop, allowing a user to view results and modify files.

## User Interface Changes

Users wishing to run all steps of a task together may continue to do so the same way they do now, writing segway <task>. 

To run a single step, use the command segway <task>-<step>. For example, segway identify-run will run the identify associated programs. 

A change to all users will be the order of the positional arguments and additional arguments provided to segway. Now users will only be able to specify arguments specific to each task, rather than having a downstream error occur. This means that the commands must now follow the order:

`"segway [GLOBAL_OPTION] TASK [TASK_OPTION] GENOMEDATA [GENOMEDATA ...] TRAINDIR [IDENTIFYDIR]"`

Where global options are those that apply to all tasks such as cluster arguments. Task options are those that are specific to the desired task.
update.title: Split Segway Tasks into Steps

content.raw: @{557058:c80ca578-03a1-4ac6-b3ee-50372a3fceee} This is ready for your review again.
content.html: @Eric Roberts This is ready for your review again.

Where global options are those that apply to all tasks such as cluster arguments. Task options are those that are specific to the desired task.
update.title: Split Segway Tasks into Steps

content.raw: In general, the look-before-you-leap pattern is disfavored in Python and we should avoid it.

content.raw: Looks like you can find whether it previously existed by using `io.open()` instead of `__builtins__.open()` and then using `job_log_file.tell()` to see whether you were already at the end of the file. Also leave a comment that in Python 3 `io.open()` and `__builtins__.open()` are the same so after Py2 support is gone we can remove.
content.html: Looks like you can find whether it previously existed by using io.open() instead of __builtins__.open() and then using job_log_file.tell() to see whether you were already at the end of the file. Also leave a comment that in Python 3 io.open() and __builtins__.open() are the same so after Py2 support is gone we can remove.
